moves.1. Nf3: I've gotta confess, I was not feeling too good about seeing this.  I haven't faced 1. Nf3 before, and so I figured my best option was to just do some safe, kingside developing for awhile and wait for white to make a commitment.
moves.1... Nf6 2. g3: no commitment yet, so I'm content to think about Nf6, g6, Bg7, and 0-0, and go from there.
moves.2... g6 3. Bg2: Still no reason to think otherwise...
moves.3... Bg7 4. O-O O-O 5. d3: At this point, I said to myself that if he's not going to make a bid for the center, then *I will*.
moves.5... d5: For better or worse, I'm staking my claim.
moves.6. Re1 c5: And this seemed a logical follow-up.  If he's going to give me a space advantage, I'll gladly take it.
moves.7. Nbd2: Was he planning Nb3?  After all, my c-pawn is defenseless with my dark-squared bishop on g7.
moves.8. c3: Really giving me a free big center.  (Sound like an internet giveaway!)
moves.8... e5: So here we are -- and I don't know if he's going to strike back with e4 or let me have the center.
moves.9. e4: I like this move!  Things look very even and there's a lot of tension now.
moves.9... d4: Gives him c4 as a knight outpost, but gives me a space advantage and blocks in his Bg2.  (Also blocks in my Bg7...)
moves.10. Nc4: As expected, and threatening to win the e5 pawn.
moves.10... Bg4: A nice tactical defense of the e-pawn, as the pin on the knight is strong.
moves.11. h3: and so white decides it must be broken.
moves.11... Bxf3: Practically forced, as Bh5 get embarrassed by g4, and any other move surrenders the e-pawn.
moves.12. Qxf3 b5: And now this boots the knight, giving black his space advantage after all!  (It's a nice feeling to set a goal and succeed!)
moves.13. Nd2: I was feeling good with a space advantage here, even though I didn't have the 2 bishops, and so I got a little careless.
moves.13... Bh6: Black's bishop didn't look like it had much scope, so I prepared to exchange bishops when the knight moves.
moves.14. Qd1: There was, apparently, nothing for the queen on the kingside except to block in white's own f-pawn.
moves.14... Rc8: with the idea of an eventual c5, gaining even more space.
moves.15. Kh2 Qd7: ...and as I made this move, I thought "now just look out for h4 and Bh3," and wasn't prepared when white played...
moves.16. Nb3: Threatening Nxc5 and Bxh6.  Of course, I *forgot* about the Bc1.  Yes, yes I did.  I'm rated over 1700 and I remembered pinning the knight, but forgot about the bishop when the knight moved.  And so logically, I played...
moves.16... c4: ?  This loses the exchange and a pawn, as white demonstrates.
moves.17. Bxh6 cxb3 18. Bxf8 Kxf8 19. axb3:
And now white has a large advantage.  I would say white has a won game here, and just needs to avoid a blunder to convert this into a full point.

At this juncture, I was pretty disillusioned, and needed to come up with a plan.
moves.19... Ne7: Building up pressure on the c-pawn was the best I could come up with.
moves.20. Qd2: Qg5 would be dreadful right now!
moves.20... Nc6: I realized I needed to defend e5 in the event of Qg5, and was mad at myself for wasting a move.
moves.22... Nge7 23. f4: white is threatening to blow open the center with devastation for black after exf4.
moves.24. Ref1: Uncomfortable for black's king, no doubt.
moves.24... Kg7: I felt that this was forced.
moves.25. h4: Now this tactic I saw -- allowing the skewer of Bh3 would be bad news for black.
moves.25... Qd6: I had to keep my pieces active.
moves.26. Bh3: And now the rook's got to move, too.
moves.26... Rc7: This keeps up some pressure on the c-pawn, which I figured was my only chance for counterplay.  With white's pieces scattered and cramped, he can't maneuver as easily as I can, so my material disadvantage isn't as dreadful as it would seem on a more open board.
moves.27. f5:
But white's coming after me, and threatening to blow the game open.  I figured I had to try and strike back, and hope to get lucky.

Boy, anyone who's read my annotated games must notice this is a recurring theme!
moves.27... b4: I can't even give this more than a "?!", because after 28. c4, black has nothing to play against.
moves.28. g4: ? for white, and a chance at life for me!  Notice that the last 4 white moves have left white's king quite exposed...
moves.28... bxc3: Not giving anyone a second chance to play c4.
moves.29. bxc3 dxc3 30. Qa2: I was hoping white would be scared to play Qxc3 because of the discovered attack from the rook, but in hindsight, I think he should have.
moves.30... Nd4: I may be down the exchange, but having more space and the passed c3 pawn gave me a tremendous amount of hope...
moves.31. Rfc1: ?  This leaves white's king without defenders, and so I knew it was time to go for broke.  After a day or so of calculating variations, I decided to go for it...
moves.31... Nf3+: And it's pretty clear that Qxd3 is unavoidable.
moves.32. Kg3: Aggressive, but this steps into danger.  Kg2 looked safer to me.
moves.32... Qxd3: A quiet but dangerous move, threatening a lot of things.
moves.33. Bf1: This was a nice try, I thought, to force the queen to move.
moves.33... Qxe4: And now I've regained material equality.  I feel like a swindler already.
moves.34. Qg2: ?  White appears to be threatening to win black's knight, but black has an amazing shot, that amazingly, I found...
moves.34... Nxf5+: !  Do you know how hard it is to fight to regain material equality and then, upon doing it, to *immediately* sacrifice a piece?  I thought white would play Kh3, and have to contend with N5xh4, threatening the queen, and a possible mate in the corner.
moves.35. gxf5: ?  But this allows black to win easily.
moves.35... Qf4+: !  An easy move that maybe doesn't deserve an exclam, but White has to choose between Kh3 Qxh4# and Kf2, losing the queen.
moves.36. Kf2: Better to lose the queen than get mated...
moves.37. Kg1 Nxg2: And just like that, the tables have turned.
moves.38. Bxg2 Qxf5:
And at this point, I think the prospect of having to contend with four connected passed pawns was too much for white, and he resigned.

This was a good game, and as long as mistakes are possible, victory is possible.  Hope you enjoyed it!

Ethan
